content.description: The Shark Fin is a slightly overhanging, juggy arete on a wild free-standing pillar. Climb the arete using the edge and jugs just left. Low tide is a must.
content.location: The Shark Fin is 60 feet southwest of the "boot". Traverse the summit and downclimb the west face(5.1).

content.description: If the sand is low enough sit start under the ledge and try to miss the boulder by your ass. Crux down low, settles down for the top out.  Stemming, good edges and some toehook beta for the s√†vvy. Be careful of choss up top. Finish slow and check holds. I cleaned some off but I'm sure there is more.
content.protection: We used a Pad, be careful off rocks behind you.
content.location: After top out, scramble east towards the ocean for a V1 downclimb.

content.description: Good warmup with a highball top out. Cool little shelf to get on top of right before the top out.
content.location: About 30 feet south of the Boot on South Houda, on the south facing wall.

content.description: Yard out the big jugs of several variations on the overhanging north face of the "Boot". High enough to get you mentally warmed up for the taller problems to the south, but super positive holds.
content.location: The "Boot" is the boulder that looks like one. It is about 100 yards south of the south trail stairs.

content.description: Pretty decent warm up problem along with warming up to working highball problems as well as learning to gauge chossiness of rock. Starts between the Arete on the left and the crack to the right, same start as Nerve Counseling, but then continues to follow the arete to the left for a more exposed overhang. Facing the problem, you should be facing north. Rated for amount of Choss. Be Careful.
content.location: South Houda about 260 yards down the beach from where the south trail stairs hit the beach, opposite the beach/cove from Black Wall Arete.

content.description: Pretty decent warm up problem along with warming up to working highball problems as well as learning to gauge chossiness of rock. Starts between the Arete on the left and the crack to the right and goes straight up a slight overhang to a vertical topout about 15 feet up. Facing the problem you should be facing north. Rated for amount of Choss. Be Careful.
content.location: South Houda about 260 yards down the beach from where the south trail stairs hit the beach, opposite the beach/cove from Black Wall Arete.

content.description: Nice traverse starting right and ending left. Only accessible earlier in the season when sand levels are low. Crux is the transition from the mid section to the final section of the traverse. Final section (Juguysko Jam) can be finished in one of three ways and is its own problem when the sand levels are higher. Stay low for a V5 finish, cut across the middle for a V4 finish, or go high and finish the traverse along the top for a continued V3 finish.
content.location: Across the small cove from the Rodney King, or ~130 yards from the bottom of the stairs, North facing wall

content.description: Fun problem as long as the sand is low enough. Crawl up and along the top for a V3 problem. Stay super low for V5 problem. Make your way across the face for a V4 problem.
content.location: 130 yards from the bottom of the stairs

content.description: Jugtacular is the name given to this problem by Paul Humphrey and it definitely describes this climb well! Jugtacular starts just around the corner and to the right of the Black Wall Arete. Start low, just to the left of a blocky ledge, and start pulling. Pocketed, interesting jugs(there is a sloper or two as well) will take you straight up through the bulging roof. As you hit the lip, let your feet cut loose and heel hook to more great holds above. This is a tall and exposed line that rages from 20-30 feet depending on sand conditions.
content.location: Jugtacular is on the west face of the Black Wall. The Black Wall is about 300 yards south of the Houda South stairs. See Black Wall Arete for more.

content.description: A traverse on positive, large holds that starts from the west end of the rock. Start on either the south or north side for a little variety. Fun to lap as a finish to your day. Also, a good one for new climbers.
content.location: The "Boot" is the boulder of that general shape that lies about 100 yards south of the south trail stairs.

content.description: The Black Wall is the farthest south of the tall, steep walls at Houda South. The Arete problem climbs just left of the prominent right arete of this striking wall. There is often a small stream flowing along the base that you step across to pull onto the rock. Depending on where the stream is flowing, you can start directly on the arete or slightly left for a more challenging problem. This is a highball problem but the holds are big and positive up top.
content.location: The Black wall is about 300 yards down the beach from where the south trail stairs hit the beach. This wall is easily identified as the north facing black wall with seeps and bright green algae strips on its left side. Also it is the last tall, steep feature as you walk south toward Moonstone.
